Game Rewind | UK runs away from Providence

The Cats and Friars tip off at 2 p.m. at Rupp Arena.

Game Rewind | UK runs away from Providence

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 4:02 p.m. EST November 30, 2014

Kentucky's Karl-Anthony Towns (12) shoots under pressure from Providence's Carson Desrosiers (33) during the first half of an NCAA college basketball game, Sunday, Nov. 30, 2014, in Lexington, Ky. (AP Photo/James Crisp)(Photo: James Crisp, AP)

3 CONNECT 12 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Refresh regularly (or click here) for updates during the University of Kentucky's 2 p.m. Sunday basketball game against Providence at Rupp Arena.

Final: UK 58, Providence 38.

Said coach John Calipari: "When you have this many guys that respect each other, it's about energy. We did not start the game with the kind of energy we needed, and then that White (Platoon) group came in and changed it. We still didn't get up, but the energy changed, and eventually we kind of wore them down."

See final stats: http://bit.ly/11FPV01

Watch Calipari's press conference: http://cjky.it/14zHOUo

FINAL: No. 1 Kentucky 58, Providence 38. Friars went 4 of 29 for the final 27:41. Just remarkable. Scored 16 in the second half.

— Kyle Tucker (@KyleTucker_CJ) November 30, 2014

Final stats from another routine, 20-point win over a ranked opponent. UK 58, Providence 38: http://t.co/4CVltI1p4npic.twitter.com/OqHD6PYb7f

— Jonathan Lintner (@JonathanLintner) November 30, 2014

2:34, 2H: Ed Cooley just burned his last timeout. It's too late for Providence to make a run. The Cats have subbed in waves and again pulled away late, with a lob to Dakari Johnson the latest exclamation point on a big day for the Cats, who lead 55-36.

3:46, 2H: UK's in control, up double digits on another top 25 team at the under-four timeout. The Cats lead Providence 51-34.

By the way, UK football coach Mark Stoops has issued a statement on offensive coordinator Neal Brown's move to Troy, which is now official: http://cjky.it/1FGQCU7

The thing about Kentucky is that Providence has succeeded in making the game ugly, UK hasn't played especially well, and yet Cats are up 17.

— Adam Himmelsbach (@AdamHimmelsbach) November 30, 2014

5:06, 2H: Andrew Harrison just made good on a questionable 3-point shot he bricked off the back rim, grabbing a steal and finishing with a dunk to push UK ahead 49-34.

7:18, 2H: UK's lead remains 15 points -- 44-29 -- though Karl-Anthony Towns will have a pair of free throws out of the under-eight timeout with a chance to extend it. Towns is leading the scoring column for the Cats with 10 points. Willie Cauley-Stein has 9 and Alex Poythress 6.

8:16, 2H: Willie Cauley-Stein tipped a pass and ran the court but missed an open layup. Tyler Ulis then missed the follow. But Ulis grabbed the rebound, turned and used the glass to slink in a jumper.

The next time up, Devin Booker hit UK's first 3-pointer, and Alex Poythress followed with a layup.

Timeout, Providence. UK leads 44-29, finally creating some separation from a pesky bunch of Friars.

Love how Tyler Ulis controls tempo and commands the offense. He's so underrated.

— Jeff Goodman (@GoodmanESPN) November 30, 2014

10:36, 2H: Providence, which started 7 of 10 from the field today, is now 10 of 30 but still trails just 35-29 at the under-12 timeout. UK hasn't made the most of its trips to the free throw line, where the Cats are 7 of 13, and the Friars have a 24-21 rebounding edge.

Marcus Lee, by the way, has seen a bit of a diminished role. Willie Cauley-Stein remained on the court with the White Platoon, playing in the frontcourt alongside of Dakari Johnson and Trey Lyles.

That 3-point streak dates back to 1988.

12:16, 2H: UK's lengthy streak of games with a 3-pointer made is in jeopardy. The Cats, ahead 33-27, are 0 for 3 from beyond the arc today.

14:04, 2H: Providence point guard Kris Dunn is limping a bit, and the Cats are starting to pull away. What appeared an Aaron Harrison floater turned out a lob to Karl-Anthony Towns, who absorbed a foul and hit the free throw to complete a 3-point play. UK leads 33-25, its largest advantage of the day.

15:25, 2H: Dakari Johnson picked up his third foul heading into the under-16 timeout, the Cats still ahead 30-25.

Kentucky won its first six by 40, 19, 32, 24, 58 and 48, an average of 36.8 points. Providence down five with under 15 to play.

— Kyle Tucker (@KyleTucker_CJ) November 30, 2014

15:54, 2H: Alex Poythress stole and dunked before his defensive rebound led to a Dakari Johnson jumper. With UK back ahead five points, timeout Providence. Of minor concern, Karl-Anthony Towns is on the Cats' bench with three fouls.

17:03, 2H: Providence surpassed 10 minutes without a field goal before Carson Desrosiers buried a 3-pointer to pull the Friars back to within 26-25 of UK, which hasn't scored this half.

20:00, 2H: It's a return to platoons -- specially, UK's White group of Tyler Ulis, Devin Booker, Trey Lyles, Marcus Lee and Dakari Johnson -- out to start the second half.

Meanwhile, Kansas, a blowout loser to the Cats in the Champions Classic earlier this month, held on to beat Michigan State this afternoon, strengthening UK's schedule.

The 32-point loss to Kentucky may wind up being a blessing for Kansas. Jayhawks were razor sharp this weekend in Orlando. Three solid wins.

— Jon Rothstein (@JonRothstein) November 30, 2014

Halftime: UK ramped up its defense heading into the locker room and came away with a 26-22 lead, with 10 of those points off turnovers.

John Calipari went away from his set platoons near the break. At the buzzer, the Cats' coach had the Harrison twins, Devin Booker, Trey Lyles and Willie Cauley-Stein on the floor.

At the half, ESPN analyst Seth Greenberg noted Providence is threatening because of the way Ed Cooley's team has controlled the game's pace, using most of the shot clock on offense and sagging into a zone on defense.

First half stats for Kentucky, which leads Providence 26-22 and has 10 points off TOs: http://t.co/4CVltI1p4npic.twitter.com/6ViA6JQksW

— Jonathan Lintner (@JonathanLintner) November 30, 2014

2:33, 1H: Providence coach Ed Cooley called his second timeout of this game after a Karl-Anthony Towns dunk extended the Cats' advantage to 23-20 -- their largest of the game.

3:12, 1H: As a Willie Cauley-Stein layup gives UK the lead at 21-20, some strange news confirmed by The Courier-Journal's Kyle Tucker -- walk-ons Sam Malone and Tod Lanter have been suspended for a violation of team rules.

UK spokesman confirms walk-ons Sam Malone and Tod Lanter have been suspended for a violation of team rules.

— Kyle Tucker (@KyleTucker_CJ) November 30, 2014

3:48, 1H: On one end, Tyler Ulis -- the shortest scholarship player on UK's roster -- blocked a Providence 3-point attempt. On the other, the Cats' point guard hit a runner that has his team to within 19-18 of the Friars at the under-four timeout. For the game now, UK's 7 of 18 from the field and continues to be out-rebounded 10-8. Notably, Providence starting point guard Kris Dunn has 5 turnovers.

5:00, 1H: Providence's slow-down style is working at both ends. The Friars are using the shot clock up on offense and dropping back into a zone on defense, sometimes switching to a more match-up, man-to-man look out of that. The score remains 19-15.

Providence 19, Kentucky 15, 5:34 first half. Friars frustrating the Cats, making them defend for a full shot clock, then making. UK missing.

— Kyle Tucker (@KyleTucker_CJ) November 30, 2014

5:33, 1H The White Platoon is still on the court, and Providence's Kris Dunn is still making plays, most recently nabbing a steal with the Friars up 19-15. At the other end, UK swiped a steal of its own, but Trey Lyles committed a double dribble. After a Providence timeout, the Friars will have the ball back.

7:17, 1H: UK's offense appeared stymied. The Cats were passing outside of the perimeter, baffled by Providence's matchup zone. Then talent took over, with Alex Poythress the beneficiary of an alley-oop lob. But the Friars, as they have all game, answered at the other end with a Kris Dunn layup. It's 17-14 Providence at the under-eight timeout.

10:14, 1H: The White Platoon remained in after the break, and the Cats got a pair of free throws from Dakari Johnson (14 of 16 over the last two games) and a runner in the lane from Devin Booker to break their scoring drought. They trail 14-12.

Providence passing the ball in the interior better than anyone I've seen vs. UK this year. Friars lead 15-12, 9:55 left in 1st.

— Adam Himmelsbach (@AdamHimmelsbach) November 30, 2014

11:02, 1H: Heading into the under-12 timeout, UK's missed each of its last five shots. Meanwhile, Providence is on a 12-2 run over six minutes and leads 12-8 on a Ladontae Henton 3-pointer.

12:24, 1H: From a 6-0 hole, Providence has rallied to take a 9-8 lead on UK. Center Carson Desrosiers has 5 of the Friars' points, and they're out-rebounding the Cats 7-2.

13:42, 1H: A fast-paced opening left UK's starting platoon in through a late under-16 media timeout with the Cats ahead 8-7. Karl-Anthony Towns picked up his first foul at the break but leads UK with 4 early points.

Texas, by the way, got a game-winner with 2.2 seconds to play at UConn. It'll be a top 10 matchup when the Cats and Longhorns meet Friday night.

Texas visits No. 1 Kentucky Friday. They have the bigs to at least make it interesting.

— Adam Zagoria (@AdamZagoria) November 30, 2014

14:33, 1H: Providence has nearly matched UK's hot-shooting start, connecting on 3 of 5 shots to open. It's an 8-7 Cats lead.

16:02, 1H: The Cats and Friars waited only so long for TV. Under way at Rupp Arena, Karl-Anthony Towns hit UK's first bucket and Andrew Harrison added another as part of a 3 for 3 start. The Cats lead 6-3.

20:00, 1H: UK will send out its regular Blue Platoon to start this one, while Providence lists hobbling starting point guard Kris Dunn in its lineup. Dunn, a former McDonald's All American, averages 7 assists.

By the way, Michigan State leads Kansas 36-35 at the half while Texas and UConn battle to the buzzer.

The tip at Rupp Arena should hold for TV, which is waiting on Longhorns-Huskies to finish up.

Late start in Rupp Arena not ESPN's fault, #BBN. Game management guys off by 5 minutes. Sorry about that.

— Fran Fraschilla (@franfraschilla) November 30, 2014

PREGAME: We'll learn plenty about the Cats today, who in facing No. 25 Providence will also get final scores from a pair of noteworthy games around the country.

Current No. 7 Texas, the Cats' next opponent, is locked in a battle with 24th-ranked UConn. And as UK battles the Friars, Kansas and Michigan State are dueling in the Orlando Classic's championship game.

So along with what's happening at Rupp Arena, expect some updates on those as well.

Best way for Kentucky fans to get past a football loss to Louisville... pic.twitter.com/o3D6vHf9mN

— Adam Himmelsbach (@AdamHimmelsbach) November 30, 2014

--Two things to watch for UK: Can Devin Booker, who's averaged 17.3 points per game in the Cats' last three, remain hot? And will the defense, which hasn't allowed a foe to shoot better than 38 percent all season, follow?

--The Friars, who may play Sunday without starting point guard Kris Dunn (ankle), are in the top 25 of the Coaches Poll for the first time since the end of the 2004 season. They're receiving votes in the AP Top 25.

--Providence and UK have met just twice -- in the 1976 NIT and then last season at the Barclays Center. The Cats won both matchups.

--Against No. 1 teams, Providence is 2-11 all time. The most-recent victory came in 2009 over then-Big East Conference rival Pittsbrugh.

--For more pregame reading, check out a game preview featuring Dakari Johnson's improved free throw shooting (http://cjky.it/1vYHniD) as well as matchups and story lines (http://cjky.it/1y9IQCR) from UK beat writer Kyle Tucker.

Once a year a UK game coincides with a gun show adjacent to Rupp and I'm briefly terrified until I realize that's it. pic.twitter.com/7WrUuCz1K5

— Kyle Tucker (@KyleTucker_CJ) November 30, 2014

Projected UK Blue Platoon

G Andrew Harrison

G Aaron Harrison

F Alex Poythress

F Willie Cauley-Stein

F Karl-Anthony Towns

Projected UK White Platoon

G Tyler Ulis

G Devin Booker

F Trey Lyles

F Marcus Lee

C Dakari Johnson

Projected Providence Starters

G Junior Lomomba

G Kyron Cartwright

F LaDontae Henton

F Tyler Harris

C Carson Desrosiers
